title: Fibromyalgia and Guilt

content: A week ago, my brother and sister-in-law’s little farm north of Columbus, OH, was destroyed by a tornado.

The storm demolished their chicken coops, sheds, walk-in coolers, trailer, and hoop houses. It yanked the roof off the barn and soaked the sheep with rain. The woods where my brother hunted and the dogs played in the creek now resembles a lumber yard.
Dave and Erin were safe in their house with their dogs, sheltered in the basement. I feel so very grateful that they’re alive.
I also feel so very guilty that I can’t help them rebuild. Fibromyalgia won’t let me.
What a jerk.
I can’t help them pick up trash around the property or round up the chickens that survived.
I can’t take the sheep out to pasture or take the dogs for a walk.
I can’t go to Lowe’s and load up wheelbarrows full of supplies.
I can’t salvage anything that could be Frankenstein-ed into something useful.

content: I can’t help because I can’t be on my feet for longer than 10 minutes. The fibromyalgia pain in my lower back and upper buttocks gets so excruciating that I weep.
It’s not my fault that I have a health condition that limits me, but I still feel guilty.
My aunt’s funeral (my father’s sister) took place 2 weeks before the tornado.

I kept sitting down during the calling hours. When I saw a loved one, I’d get up, give them a hug, chat until being on my feet got too painful, and then I’d retreat to one of the cushioned chairs on the outer edges of the room.
I felt guilty.

I wondered if I hurt their feelings by cutting the conversation short. I worried that people were straining their backs leaning over to talk with me while I sat. And I felt bad when I flinched because someone’s hug squeezed one of my tender points.
I also feel guilty when fibromyalgia forces me to ask for help for myself. I need all the help I can get when I’m in a flare-up.

content: I’m extremely fortunate that I have a family generous with their time, strength, and energy. When I need help, my mom will wash my dishes, my aunt will get me groceries, and my dad will mow my lawn. I’ve lived in my house for 2 years now and not once have I mowed my lawn. (Thank you, Dad!)
Fibromyalgia triggers guilt all the time, really.
I feel guilty when I leave a get-together early because of the fatigue. I feel like I’m letting people down and insulting the hosts.
I feel guilty when I don’t meet my friends for Sunday services at our church. It’s the only time of the week when sleeping in feels optional, and it’s hard not to take advantage of it.
I feel guilty that I can’t carry my own luggage into the beach house when I go on vacation with my family.
I suppose that guilt is a complication of fibromyalgia. It tags along. It’s yet another obstacle to deal with.

Something that involves sitting down.
